metadata.story_name: The Hamilton Family's Easter Delight: 1786 Edition

writing_prompt: On a bright Easter morning in 18th-century New York, Alexander and Eliza Hamilton navigate the chaos of excited children, church services, and a backyard egg hunt, cherishing the simple joys of family and the traditions that bring them closer together.
story:
Alexander popped one eye open as he heard the doorknob wriggle from the outside. Eliza heard it too; letting out an exasperated sigh.
"Darling, it seems we're on the verge of an invasion," Alexander remarked, a mischievous smile gracing his lips as he leaned in to give her a tender kiss.
They both sat up as the door flew open and Phillip charged in excitedly, followed by his two-year-old sister Angelica. Eliza picked up her daughter, while her son climbed up onto the bed so that he was between his parents.
"Guess what? It's Easter!" Phillip exclaimed; his eyes gleaming with excitement.
Eliza ran a hand through her son’s dark hair, “Yes, sweetheart.” She kissed his cheek. “Happy Easter, Phillip.”
“Happy Easter, Papa, Mama!” Phillip exclaimed, giving them each a hug.
Angelica repeated in a high squeak, “Happy Easter!”
Alexander squeezed his children, kissing each on the head with a chuckle. "Happy Easter, my little lambs," he said, feeling grateful for the joy and love in his family.
“Can we go look for Easter eggs, mama?” Phillip looked up to his mother eagerly.
Eliza frowned, “Now Phillip, you know we are going to church first.”
Phillip’s face fell in disappointment for a moment. Then his eyes lit up. “Can we after church?”
Eliza sighed, “Yes dear, we can.” She kissed his forehead again. “Now, go get dressed so we can have breakfast.”
“Yay!” Phillip yelled as he slid off the bed and tore out of the room before Eliza could admonish him.
Eliza shook her head, “That boy sometimes…”
“Ah, he should enjoy this day, my dear.“ Alexander laughed a little.
Eliza smiled at her husband, “I know, I just want him to remember the real reason for Easter.”
“I’m sure he will, Eliza. He’s a smart boy,” Alexander reassured her.
She smiled, “He gets that from his papa.” Eliza groaned and got up out of the bed with Angelica, who she set on the floor and took her hand. She was eight months pregnant with their third child. Eliza chuckled as the little girl tried to keep up with her waddling pace.
"You're going to be a big sister soon, Angelica. Are you excited to meet your new baby brother or sister?"
Angelica nodded eagerly, her young face lighting up with excitement. Eliza couldn't wait to see the bond that would form between her children, just like the one she shared with her sisters.
“Sweetheart, do you want me to get Angie dressed?” Alexander offered, looking lovingly at his wife.
“No, I’ll be fine, Alexander. Just go see that our son is, will you?” She instructed while padding out the door with their daughter.
Alexander yawned, pushed the covers aside, and stretched, a smile spreading across his face as he gazed at the blossoming tree and clear blue sky outside the window. Today would be a good day indeed.
~*~
At breakfast, the family were treated to Dutch pancakes that were thin versions of French crepes, eggs, and salmon. Coffee was prepared for the adults and orange juice for the children, the oranges being an Easter gift from the Schuyler's, as well as fruit preserves for the table. Philip eagerly shared his strategy for finding the most eggs, while little Angelica insisted on wearing her best bonnet for the occasion.
At its end, Alexander reclined in his chair and grinned. “That was the most delicious breakfast! We shall have to send a note to your father to thank him for the things he sent down for us.”
She nodded before looking up at the clock. “We had best hurry; we don’t want to be late for church.” Eliza glanced over to her son. “Phillip, you may get down. Go put on your coats and wait for us.”
After ten minutes, the family of four strolled through the bustling streets of New York City on their way to Trinity Church, enjoying the fresh April breeze. They looked up at the blossoming trees and birds. Eliza held Angelica in one arm while holding Phillip’s hand with her left. Alexander held his son’s other one while Alexander pointed out the birds flying to various trees.
“Look Phillip, there’s a blue jay,” Alexander exclaimed. "That's a sure sign that spring is here if they are back from wintering in the south."
“Wow, look at it fly!” Phillip responded; his eyes wide with wonder.
As they entered the church, Eliza and Alexander greeted their friends and neighbors with warm smiles and handshakes. They took their seats in the pew near the front, holding hands as they listened to the priest as they said hymns, prayers, and readings. The church was filled with the sound of hymns being sung by the congregation, creating a sense of peace and unity among those gathered.
After the service, Eliza and Alexander stayed behind to chat with their friends, discussing the message of the sermon and sharing updates on their lives. Seeing her son getting antsy, Eliza smiled. “You’ll have to forgive us, it’s time for us to go home and search for Easter eggs.”
~*~
Alexander's face lit up with a smile as he observed his little ones exploring the backyard, clutching small baskets in their hands, eagerly hunting for Easter eggs. Eliza leaned against her husband, resting her head on his shoulder, a peaceful smile gracing her face as she watched their children. Her smile widened even further as she heard their delighted squeals of joy each time they discovered another hidden treasure. The previous night, after Phillip and Angelica had gone to sleep, Eliza and Alexander had spent time together, meticulously boiling and dyeing eggs using natural ingredients like onion skins, beet juice, madder root, dandelion greens, and coffee grounds.
It had been a labor of love, but the look of wonder on their children's faces made it all worth it. As the kids ran around the yard, their laughter filling the air, Alexander couldn't help but feel grateful for his family. He wrapped an arm around Eliza, pulling her close as they watched their children continue their Easter egg hunt. Eliza rubbed her large belly and turned to Alexander and whispered, "This is such a beautiful day, isn't it? I'm so grateful for our family and for moments like these."
Alexander nodded and kissed her forehead, his heart full of love. "Yes, it truly is. I feel blessed every day to have you and our children by my side. I hope we can continue this tradition for many more years with them."
They sat in comfortable silence, watching their children laugh and play in the early spring sun. Surrounded by love and happiness, Alexander couldn't help but feel at peace, knowing that they were building memories that would last a lifetime.

writing_prompt: As a rare solar eclipse casts an eerie twilight over Washington's camp, tensions rise among the soldiers who see it as either a divine omen or a harbinger of doom. Amid the celestial spectacle, whispers of unease grow—what if the eclipse brings more than just darkness?
story:
Summer had taken full possession of the Eastern Coast. Washington’s troops were buzzing about the camp, readying for a campaign at Monmouth Courthouse that was to commence four days hence. But that was not the only event that was bringing about both excitement and fear among the men; on the 24th of June, there was to be a solar eclipse that had been reported in newspapers at the beginning of January.
Nothing in Washington’s inner circle had changed despite the solar event. Battle plans were still being drawn up, the office was busy with more correspondence being written, orders were being directed by the Commander-in-Chief of the army. The aides-de-camp were not so busy as that they scarcely discussed topics that were not related to the upcoming battle at dinner. Except for tonight, when they had a reprieve long enough to talk about something else.
“Did you see the newspaper today? There’s to be a solar eclipse the day after tomorrow.” John said between the bits of his meager stew of salted beef and potatoes.
“Some of the soldiers are calling it a bad omen it being so close to the upcoming battle.” Alexander sighed and rolled his eyes.
Lafayette shrugged, “I see it as a good omen. The brightness of the Revolution, the periods of darkness where we’ve lost battles, and the sun re-appearing means our cause will shine brightly again with won battles.”
‘You are very optimistic,
Mon Ami
.” Laurens said with a quirked smile.
“Though I will admit that I have not ever seen a solar eclipse before in my life. It will be interesting to observe it given the chance.”  Meade returned.
“Nor I. Let’s just hope we’re not overwhelmed with paperwork.” Hamilton added dryly.
“I mean, it’s not going to be hard to miss, really.” Laurens laughed.
As the group continued to discuss the upcoming solar eclipse and its possible implications, the conversation in the room shifted again towards the coming battle at Monmouth.
Alexander would be glad of the distraction of this celestial event to calm his nerves about the fight. There was something in the air that made him uneasy. He felt something was going to go wrong.
*~*
The hours before the eclipse was just as busy as usual. Washington’s aides-de-camp were kept busy with their work, all the while tilting their heads out the window to keep an eye on the sky or their pocket watches.
“I don’t think a few minutes break would go amiss.” Hamilton remarked, putting down his quill and capping his ink.
Lafayette grinned, “You read my mind, mon ami!”
The others chuckled while putting away their writing utensils and pushed back their chairs. Each of them stretched, grateful for the exercise after so many hours seated. They all stepped outside onto the small patch of dirt generously called a lawn and stared up, with their hands over their foreheads to shield them from sunlight.
Meade pulled out his pocket watch and glanced at it. “It should be starting any time now. The newspaper said the eclipse should begin at 3:19 pm.”
It doesn’t look as though it has changed.” Alexander remarked squinting up at the sun.
“Alex, don’t look directly at the sun, you idiot!” Laurens snapped.
Hamilton closed his eyes sharply then winced. He slowly opened them, squinting and shielding them with his hand. He stayed still for a few moments, adjusting to the brightness.
Finally, at 3:30, as the sky began to dim, the soldiers began to gasp. Lafayette and Laurens leaped up from the stairs.
"It's beginning!" Lafayette shouted, standing on his tiptoes as if trying to catch a glimpse of the sky. "Look at that!" Lafayette exclaimed, pointing up at the darkening sky.
The Moon slowly began to creep in front of the sun, the group watched in awe as the sky grew darker and a strange twilight settled over the land.
Slowly, the sun became more and more obscured, the crescent becoming smaller and smaller as the smaller body of the Moon overtook it.  A sense of anticipation filled the air. Meade felt a shiver run down his spine, a mixture of excitement and wonder at the celestial event unfolding before their eyes.
The whole camp seemed to hold its breath as the moon completely covered the sun, casting a shadow over their little part of the world. The temperature dropped, and a hush fell over the group as they experienced the breathtaking beauty of the total solar eclipse.
“
C’est Incroyable
!” Lafayette whispered in awe. "Mon Dieu! But it’s like dawn!”
“Look at that bright light at the right corner.” Alexander remarked, “I wonder if that is the sun re-appearing.” He turned, tilting his head while his eyebrows furrowed. “Do you hear that?” He pointed his finger upwards. “There are no birds chirping now. I think they are just as discombobulated!”
“It’s quite a sight isn’t it, gentlemen?” A deep voice from behind them called, making them all whirl around to see the General striding towards them. The group all saluted, looking as though they were ready to take a reprimand.
“You’re Excellency,” Hamilton started, “We did not mean to abandon our duties during such a critical period before a battle-”
Washington raised his hand. "No worries. I wouldn't want to miss out on witnessing such a rare celestial phenomenon; one that we might never get to see again." He gazed up at the solar eclipse. “It’s quite a sight to see, no?”
“What do you think that ring around the sun is, sir?” Alexander wondered.
“Perhaps," Washington replied, raising his chin up to the eclipse, "it’s the atmosphere of the moon, or that of the sun.” Washington commented.
“Well, whatever it is, it sure is a beautiful sight,” Laurens added.
“It looks like light surrounding a void,” remarked Lafayette with wonder in his voice.
“That’s not eerie or anything, Lafayette,” scoffed Meade.
A few moments later, the moon began to move away from the sun, beginning to chase away the shadows. The ring of light around the sun grew brighter as the moon slowly moved out of its path. The sky gradually began to lighten.
“Sunrise again.” Laughed Alexander, his breath catching as it indeed felt as though dawn was breaking for a second time that day. It wasn’t long before afternoon sunshine returned to the sky. The soldiers murmured but went back to their duties.
The group stood in awe as the eclipse passed.  Washington turned to his companions with a smile. "Well, gentlemen, it seems we have witnessed to something truly extraordinary today. Now, shall we get back to work?”

metadata.story_name: Alexander Hamilton's No Good Very Bad Week

writing_prompt: Alexander Hamilton is determined to prove he can manage his work despite a sprained ankle, but his wife Eliza has other plans—and she’s not above enlisting unexpected allies to keep him in bed.
story:
Alexander Hamilton’s day began badly and only went downhill from there.
“Alexander! Are you awake?” Eliza called from the bottom of the stairs. “You’re going to be late!”
He sat up groggily, rubbing his hand over his face. Turning, he glanced out of the window, and met a gloomy sky. Yawning, he reached for his pocket watch to check the time. Alexander gasped; it was already ten minutes after eight am.
‘Damn!” Alexander muttered while throwing aside his bed covers and hastily made his way into the washroom where he quickly made himself ready for the day. He grabbed his coat from a chair and hurriedly made his way downstairs. Unfortunately, his foot slipped out from under him in his hurry, and he fell rear first down several steps.
“Alexander?” Eliza appeared, trying not to smile as she watched him rubbing his now sore backside, “Are you alright?”
“Mmmm, I’m fine, Eliza.” Alexander’s voice was strained in attempt to not sound cross as he stood. “I won’t be able to have breakfast this morning; I’m late as it is.” He kissed her goodbye, followed by his children who had appeared from all corners of the house and were giggling at their father’s minor misfortune.
“I’ll see you all tonight!” He called, waving goodbye as he stepped out onto the townhouse’s steps into the gloomy day. Soon enough, the gray clouds gave way to rain falling over the city. Alexander sighed, glad he had the foresight to bring his umbrella, which he popped open and headed towards his office.
*~*
At noon, Alexander stood from his office chair and glanced out the window to see rain still falling outside. He groaned, reminded that he had business in the city today. Patting his pocket to ensure that he had his check book was still there, Alexander stepped to the outer office and briefly spoke to his secretary that he’d be going out for a while. He stepped out onto the pavement and enjoyed the bustle of people. He walked down the street, nodding at people who acknowledged him on the opposite side of the sidewalk.
“Alexander!” A familiar voice called from behind him. He turned to find Aaron Burr taking long strides to catch up with him.
Alexander took on a neutral expression, hoping that is was just a passing greeting. But by the other man's rush to catch up, he knew it was more than that.
“Aaron Burr, sir, ” He answered with a pleasant mask.
“May I speak with you a moment? It’s a business matter.” Aaron asked with a professional air.
Alexander nodded to the coffee shop next door. They entered, taking in the smell of freshly roasted coffee and baked pastries. The pair sat at the bar, both awaiting their drinks in silence for a few moments. When the coffee arrived, Alexander spoke up. “What is it that you needed to speak with me about, Burr?”
“I have taken on so many case litigation referrals that I cannot handle any more. I was wondering if you were willing to take a few on?”
Alexander blew out a breath. He didn’t want to do any favors for his rival, but they were both professionals as lawyers and to refuse may reflect badly on him.
“Very well,” Alexander reached into his pocket and withdrew a few of his business cards to hand to Aaron.
“Thank you.” Aaron said quietly, taking them. He stood after draining the last dregs of his coffee. “Well, I best go. I’ve some things to do. Have a good day, Alexander.”
Alexander soon followed, glad that the impromptu meeting was over; five minutes with him was like an hour.
Rain had begun to splatter the pavement again, his shoes soaked through with it. He stepped into the quiet space of the bank,  thinking to fish out his slightly soggy checkbook, then his heart skipped a beat. Where his checkbook had been was now an empty space. Alexander’s cheeks warmed as the bank teller stood there waiting, looking somewhat exasperated with every passing moment. Hamilton flummoxed and said, “Would you excuse me?”
He hastily made his way outside, padding every pocket he had. Did Aaron….? No, but that wasn’t possible. He wasn’t a scoundrel in that way. Alexander groaned; would have to retrace his steps. He had to find that checkbook.
Alexander was so preoccupied with his thoughts that he didn’t see (or perhaps remembered) the small dip in the pavement. His foot twisted awkwardly. He let out a small cry as he felt his ankle twist and he fell to the ground, tearing the fabric of his knees.
A few passersby came to a startled stop at the scene of his fall. A man took his shoulders and helped him stand, though the pain made it difficult to remain so. “Are you alright, sir?”
Alexander winced, trying to smile through the pain that was shooting up from his ankle. “I’m…. fine.”
The look on the other man said otherwise. The man was tall and burly, wearing a brown coat, his salt and pepper hair was tied back in a queue. He looked about for a moment. “Let me help you sit, sir. Your breeches will get damp with the rain, but they’re already ruined by the look of it.”
Alexander was guided to a stoop of an apartment building, wincing in pain with each step before he was sat heavily down.
The man’s face was sympathetic. “I think you’ve twisted your ankle rather badly, sir.” So, saying he placed his hand gingerly on Hamilton’s ankle, causing his to wince with pain and recoil from the man. “Definitely twisted, if not sprained, sir.”
“Damn,” Alexander groused. This day was not turning out well for him at all. He should have just stayed in bed.
“Indeed,” the taller man agreed with a sympathetic smile. I’ll call for a carriage to take you home.”
He rushed to the street to do just that. Soon, a cab driver and the other man had his arms slung over their shoulders so to take the weight off his injured leg. When he was safely ensconced in the carriage, he leaned out of the carriage to his rescuer, fishing in his pocket for a coin which he attempted to hand to him. “Might I have your name, sir?”
The man raised a hand to stop him. “No sir, I don’t want your money. My name is James Wagoner, at your service, sir.”
“Alexander nodded. “Alexander Hamilton, at yours, sir. My thanks for your assistance. With a final nod, the carriage jolted into motion.
~*~
Eliza gently lifted the pillow to readjust it under Alexander’s bandaged foot over a covered piece of ice, smiling lovingly at him.
Alexander sighed with slight annoyance. “I tire of this. My foot feels better, Eliza.”
His wife sent him a warning glare. “You are not to move until your ankle is healed, Alexander. Doctor’s orders.” She sent him a sweet smile. “You’ll just have to put up with being spoiled for a week or so.”
He sighed, “I’ve been testing my ankle, it doesn’t hurt as much; I can walk.”
Eliza’s lips pursed. “You’re still limping, Alexander. That doesn’t mean it is healed by any means. You’re not going anywhere and aggravating that injury; do you understand me?”
Alexander’s shoulder’s slumped in defeat. Eliza’s nurturing nature had always been hard to escape when he was injured or ill. His ankle still had a lingering ache and hurt when moved a certain way but felt better from days before.
“Alright, Alright.” Alexander put his hands up in defeat, sending her a winning grin, “I suppose I can put up with your pampering for a few days more, my darling.”
“Good.” She kissed his cheek. “Now, I’m going to get dinner started.” She said, moving away from the bed. “Is there anything you want before I go?”
Alexander seemed to think for a moment, Honey, do we have any cherries about the kitchen?”
Eliza contemplated for a moment and gave him a speculative look. “You ate the last of them yesterday, Alexander.”
Alexander gave her a loving glance, “Darling, you spoil me so being wounded like this. My dear, would you fetch me some more to make some cherry tarts for me?” He asked in a feigned timid voice.
At her questioning glance, he added, “Anna can look after the children.” He brought his bottom lip up in a gesture his children often employed for an extra treat or bedtime story.
She gave him a loving, but frustrated sigh. That made her laugh lightly and bend to kiss him again. “Very well, Alexander. Do me a favor and stay in bed?”
Eliza departed from the room and readied herself. Alexander occupied himself by pretending to be absorbed in a book. When he heard the door downstairs creak shut, he sat bolt upright. He threw aside his covers and limped to his wardrobe to retrieve his clothes. He sat heavily on his bed to tug on his stocking and britches. After he was dressed, he gently slid into his shoes, wincing while he tugged his injured right foot into the leather. He cursed under his breath but would not turn back now.
It had taken longer for him than he’d like to find his briefcase, which Eliza had no doubt hidden for this reason. But he soon found it and made his way downstairs, praying that he would not twist his ankle again. The effort made the bone ache, but he ignored it.
He was just about to steal out the door when he heard a small voice behind him. “Papa?”
Wheeling around and wincing, he saw Jamie behind him. “Are you going to work, today? I thought you were hurt.”
“I am not going to work, my little lamb.” He hated lying to his children, but didn’t have a choice. “Merely down the street. I won’t be long, I promise.” He ran a hand through his son’s hair. He waved cheerily at Jamie and stepped cautiously out to hail a cab.
*~*
“Alexander?” Aaron Burr blurted as he peeked his head out of his office door. “I thought you were supposed to to be home nursing your ankle.”
Alexander pressed his lips together, but waved a hand in dismissal. “I’m fine, mister Burr, sir.” But in truth, he wasn’t. The two flights of stairs to reach the offices had set his ankle on fire and made the bones ache.
Burr looked disconcerted nonetheless. He glanced at the docket in his hand, then back at him. “We don’t have any cases for you today, Alexander. We weren’t expecting you for court.” He looked behind him and then back at Alexander. “What if your wife discovers that you’re here?”
“It’s fine. I need to catch up on my casework.” Hamilton nodded, “Have a good day, Mr. Burr, sir.”
He limped down the hall to his own office and after shutting the door, weakly made his way to his office chair that he sat arduously down in with relief. Sighing, he looked over to the huge pile of cases that were stacked on his desk. He had to get back to work, he had bills to pay and his children to feed.
Twenty minutes later, Alexander felt his energy flagging. He supposed it was because of the strain his body had endured trying to get here. Feeling sleepy, he thought he’d take a short nap in his chair, then start again. He shut his eyes, feeling sleep come for him.
The door burst open and a fuming Eliza Hamilton entered, her face glowing with afternoon light from the window. “Alexander Hamilton!”
Alexander jumped, the papers in his hand flying out from it and scattering to the floor.
Burr stepped behind her, a look of both dismay and apology to his fellow lawyer. His look said
, I warned you, my friend.
Eliza charged over to Alexander and yanked him by the ear, “What are you doing at your office? You’re
supposed
to be staying off your ankle!”
He looked sheepishly, “I know, I know. But I had to get some work done or I’ll get farther behind.”
Eliza’s eyes narrowed and she grew quiet. Alexander closed his mouth at the infuriated expression and he was forced to look away at her.
“You are not indispensable, Alexander.” She said softly, with a glare. “You need to rest your foot and let it heal.” Her look was almost neutral except for the flash of anger in her eyes. “And you lied to me to get me out of the house so you can come to the office.”
Alexander averted his eyes from his wife, shamefaced. “I am sorry, Eliza. I really thought my ankle had improved.”
“When will you learn, Alexander, that your health is more important than your work?” Eliza huffed.
He stood and pushed out his office chair to reach her side, smiling apologetically. “I’m sorry my dear Eliza. Please forgive me for being so foolish.”
His wife crossed her arms over her chest, but her expression softened at Alexander’s obvious discomfort at standing on his injured foot. “Sweetheart, I just want to you to get better. And you won’t do that gallivanting all over the city.”
“You’re right, Eliza.” He stood and winced, kissing her cheek. “Let’s go home.”

metadata.story_name: If You Can't Stand the Heat

writing_prompt: During a grueling summer march with the Continental Army, Alexander Hamilton and Lafayette succumb to the oppressive heat, leaving John Laurens and General Washington scrambling to save their friends from the brink of heatstroke. How do they navigate the challenges of battlefield medicine and the bonds of friendship in the sweltering August sun?
story:
August was proving to be worse than anything John Laurens had experienced in his home state of South Carolina, made worse by wool coats they wore. The march was long and arduous as the sun beat down on the Continental Army. Alexander shifted in his saddle, watching the men behind him trudging along, slumped and quiet. The army was advancing through Maryland now; the soldiers trudging along silently, their packs clacking and footfall heavy.
He turned to them in his seat and grinned. “Not much further men! Forward to victory!” Then began to sing ‘Yankee Doodle’, which made them perk up and join in. The final refrain resulted in a cheer and laughter from the soldiers.
Next to John, Alexander grinned and turned back around to the road in front of them. Though the smile was short-lived, sweat barely visible on his skin from the heat,
“Alex,” John Laurens galloped nearer to him with a concerned glance. “You alright?”
Alexander waved a dismissive hand, “I’m fine, John...thank you.” His jaw set. “I wish we weren’t wearing these heavy things.” He plucked at the wool coat.
“Merde!” The Marquis muttered so that their Commander would not hear their complaints, “This is worse than Monmouth.” He reached for a handkerchief and dabbed his forehead. His eyes fluttered downwards. “I am so weary, and my muscles ache.”
John reached for his canteen and passed it over to Alexander and Lafayette, who both gave a nod of thanks before taking a few large swigs, then returned it to him.
Alexander sighed shakily, “This march is taking longer than I expected, we’re going slower than I hoped we would.” He pressed his own handkerchief across his skin. “I didn’t think the heat in St. Croix was terrible. This is downright oppressive!”
John gave him a discerning look. 'You look pale. Are you alright, Alex?' John asked again, "'Laff?'
“It will be better when we’ve stopped for the day.” Lafayette groaned.
Alexander looked up to the direction of the sun, “That won’t be a few hours yet.”
Lafayette sighed discontentedly.
“Colonel Laurens!” Washington’s deep timbre called him. He nodded to his friend to gallop up to their leader’s side. After a few words were exchange, John shot his friends an apologetic look. “Take care of yourselves until I get back, yeah?” Laurens galloped forward with Tilghman, out of sight in a matter of minutes.
*~*
An hour later, Laurens rode back to his friends’ side. Alexander’s head was slumped down onto his chest as though he was asleep, but his breathing seemed fast. Alarmed, Laurens put a hand to his friend’s next and pulled his hand back. Alexander’s skin was hot, but not sweating. Wedging himself between Alexander and Lafayette, he checked the Frenchman’s skin as well, equally overheated and pale.
Laurens felt panic rise within him. “Hammy!” He shouted, giving the smaller aide’s shoulder a shove. He remembered at Monmouth Alexander had succumbed to heat exhaustion after being thrown from his horse.
To his relief, the man roused, lifting his head to look at him, though his eyes were distant. “M-mother? M’ so hot. Sleepy.” His confused expression shot fear through him. “Who-? J-James?”
Laurens recognized the signs of sunstroke evident in his friends' condition. He placed a hand on Alexander as his eyes fluttered shut, and he slid sideways off his horse, only saved from falling by Laurens’s quick reflexes.
“Sir!” He called to Washington, “It’s Hamilton and Lafayette! They’re ill! Medic!”
Washington gave the signal for the convoy to stop while he turned his horse to face his three aide-de-camps, his usually passive face turned concern at the sight of Alexander and Lafayette. He grabbed for the Marquis before he too could collapse off his mount.
It had taken a few calls before Doctor Cochran rode up; his face serious. “What’s wrong?”
“I think they’re suffering from heat illness.” Laurens said quickly. He leapt off his horse and assisted getting both men off their own mounts. The doctor swiftly checked the men’s condition and confirmed Lauren’s fear." They both appeared flushed and disoriented, suffering from severe heat exhaustion.
“It’s not as severe as it could be.” Cochran said, looking up at Laurens over his glasses. “They need to be cooled down immediately, however.”
Washington assessed the situation then raised a hand to stop the convoy. “We’ll stop five miles down the road at a clearing found by Colonel Tilghman. Set up the medical tent and treat anyone else suffering from the heat. We’ll need a cart!” He directed Tilghman and McHenry to take their horses.
The men peeled away from the line and went about their directives, while the men shuffled past with looks of dismay and empathy, that neither Hamilton nor Lafayette would have warranted had they been awake.
Washington turned back to Doctor Cochran. “What can we do to assist, doctor?” His voice was slightly strained as he looked over to the two boys he considered surrogate sons.
“First of all, we need to rid them of these woolen things, then attempt to cool them down.”
“There’s a stream not too far off from here, I saw it in passing.” Laurens remarked, glancing down at Hamilton’s knitted eyebrows.
“You’ll have to carry him, sir.” Cochran remarked. “I'm afraid my strength isn’t what it used to be.”
They hurried towards the river, both cradling their ill companions gingerly in their arms, searching for a more secluded spot near the water. Laying the men on the riverbank, Washington worked to divest Lafayette of everything down to his smallclothes, Laurens doing the same for Hamilton before gathering the younger man in his arms.
“Sorry about this, Alex.” He muttered, as he settled his friend into the shallow stream, head resting against the riverbank. Alexander's hair would be muddy, but that was a minor problem to be fixed later. John held him up under the arms; the chilly water enveloped both of them. He hoped that the river’s water would cool Alexander’s mounting fever. Alexander, in the meantime, shuddered and began to thrash about.
"No Alex! Stay still! You're safe! We're just trying to cool you down." Laurens called, putting a hand to Alexander's bare shoulder.
He glanced over to see Washington’s resolute expression as he held Lafayette aloft, the doctor taking sick Frenchman’s pulse.
Laurens felt the water invading his boots but ignored it, the current sweeping around both immersed men. He checked Alexander’s forehead and found it slightly less heated.
Alexander’s eyes fluttered open, clearer than before, his gaze fixating on Laurens. “J-John.”
“Stay with me, Alex.” He said with a mixture of relief and lingering concern, scooping up a little water and pouring it over his ill friend's head.
“M-mon General?” Laurens heard Lafayette croak.
“Thank goodness, they’re beginning to come out of it.” Doctor Cochran said.
Laurens saw General Washington let out a breath between his teeth and whisper, “Thank God.”
“I don’t believe I will have to bleed either of them. They will need some time, water and rest to recover.” Doctor Cochran remarked.
"We can delay for a few days," Washington said between his breath, "but no more than that."
A cart appeared on the dirt path, pulled by a soldier and horse. Both he and General Washington took up the now sodden Major-General and trudged back up the hill to the awaiting cart, Laurens soon following with the limp form of Alexander. The cart was laden with straw, onto which they carefully loaded the men and covered them with a thin blanket to their midsections. Cochran scrambled up and perched between them, taking each man’s pulse again.
"I will ride ahead and see that the medical tent is ready,” Washington said as he mounted his horse. He nodded to Doctor Cochran and Laurens. “Take care of them.”
Laurens mounted his own horse and trotted at the same speed of the horse and cart, keeping his gaze fixed on the prone figures of Lafayette and Alexander. As cooler evening air finally began to descend, Laurens hoped for an easy recovery for his friends.

writing_prompt: In the midst of a harsh autumn during the Revolutionary War, Lafayette receives devastating news from home, leaving him torn between his duty to the American cause and his grieving family in France. How does one balance loyalty to a revolution with the ache of personal loss?
story:
Autumn’s chill mingled with rain, making day and night miserable for the Continental Army. The days had grown shorter, and the campaigns against the enemy had become more sporadic until they would draw to a close for the year. Officers and enlisted men alike found refuge in their tents on such a raw night. The last leaves on the trees were falling and snow would soon overtake the landscape in the last months of 1778.
Lafayette sat on his camp bed, the glow of the lantern filling the minimal space with light. He re-read the letter from his beloved wife for the third time that day. Adrienne had solemnly broken the news of their daughter’s death. He couldn’t stop crying. His beloved child, whom he’d known for less than a year, was now buried. He hadn’t even been able to attend the funeral, having only heard of her passing one month later.
Their first child, the beginning of their legacy, had died. Adrienne—oh, poor Adrienne! —was suffering this loss alone. He should have been there to console her at such a time. She had been with child by the time he left France to join the revolution in America.
He was met with reluctance at being given the rank of Major General and assigned to work alongside the great General Washington himself. Soon, he had shown his zeal and earnestness for the cause after being wounded at Brandywine Creek. His troops and supplies had brought much-needed relief to the Army and a gesture of goodwill to their American allies upon their arrival, but it had dwindled now to near nothing.
Lafayette ran a frustrated hand through his hair. “What on earth am I doing here?” he asked himself aloud. As he stood, the letter fluttered to his blanket. He was torn between his commitment to the Revolution in America and his bereaved wife and family in France. More than once, he had thought of going back home. But he could not leave his comrades, especially as he was now a leader among them. Gilbert felt as sense of loneliness without Adrienne, and he longed to be by her side again.
He heard a knock on the tent-pole and the familiar voice of Alexander Hamilton. "Laff? May I come in a moment?"
Lafayette turned his back to the tent flap letting out a sigh. He craved solitude to process his sorrow. Another part of him still wished for company. He tried to regain his composure by rubbing a sleeve over his eyes and inhale deeply. “Come in, Mon Ami. What brings you to my tent on such a rainy evening?”
Alexander’s face bore no smile, instead it reflected a deep sense of worry. “Laff, are you alright? You seemed…. distracted today.”
“It’s nothing, my friend.” Lafayette said airily, trying to regulate his voice so it would not tremble.
“What’s wrong, Laff? Your eyes are all red and puffy.” Alexander’s eyebrows knotted together. “Bad news from home? Not your wife?”
“Damn, you’re too good at seeing people, mon ami.” Lafayette sniffled, wiping away tears that had begun to spring anew. He picked up the letter, glancing at the words again. “My-my daughter...Henriette...passed away.” He put a hand to over his eyes again. “I... I should have been there, Alexandre. My wife will never forgive me for gallivanting to America and leaving her alone.”
Alexander’s face shifted with sympathy. “I’m so sorry Laff. I don’t think I have the words to express how regretful I am at the loss of your child.” He helped his friend sit on his bed, the cot dipping at their weight. They sat in quiet before he spoke again. “My mother….” He looked away with his own grieved look, “she died." Alexander paused, taking a breath before adding, "I remember my uncle telling my brother and I that she went to Heaven. Your daughter...she’s in Heaven.”
Lafayette’s breath hitched as his heart grappled with both grief and guilt, eyes welling with tears he let fall. He placed a tentative hand to his chest. “I didn’t even know my child for very long, Alexandre. I can’t imagine what my absence is having on the family.”
“You were fighting for a cause, Laff. I’m sure-” Alexander said putting a hand to his friend’s shoulder.
.
“Yes, but for the ideal or my ego, Alexander?” Lafayette interrupted, troubled eyes swinging towards him. “I was only given my rank in the Royal Black Guard because of my father-in-law. I had a life of privilege. I was naive when I arrived here. I thought that I would fight, and Andrienne would be waiting with my daughter.” He gave a shuddering laugh, “I dreamed of glory and adventure and selfishly left Adrienne alone and defied not only my family, but my King and Queen as well. I’ll be lucky not to be exiled when I return home.”
“Regardless of the reasons, Gilbert,” Alexander said gently, his gaze steady but still kind, “I’m sure they understand and know you mourn as well.”
Lafayette dropped his head in his hands anxiously, his voice shuddering. “Still, I don’t know what to do. To return to France or stay.”
Alexander sighed heavily. “You must do what is right in your heart, Laff. Just know that you have earned the respect of not only your own men, but the men of the Continental army; including the General and me.”
The Frenchmen allowed himself a little smile. “Merci, Alexander. I think I will just go on leave, mon ami, I will not leave the fight for your freedom.” He stared at the empty glass in his hand. “Will you raise a glass in her memory with me?” He reached for another vessel and poured some wine in his friend’s, then his own.
Alexander cleared his throat and raised his wineglass. “To your daughter.”
“To my daughter.” Lafayette echoed solemnly. They clinked their glasses together in a quiet toast and drank silently for the rest of the night.
